prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Serpens C18O
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of C18O and other CO isotopologues, DCN and H2CO toward 5 protostellar disks in Serpens, and attempt detections of N2D+ and CH3OH.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.4 km/s, but secondary science on the disk kinematics requires higher spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. Therefore we have opted to observe all target lines at a relative high spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. We have also add what is effectively a 1 GHz continuum band, though we keep it in the spectral line mode at a coarse resolution to enable serendipitous line discoveries, i.e the discovery of hot corinos toward the sample.

These sources are embedded and the largest angular scales for strong linesare thus on the arc minute scale. We are mainly interested in weaker lines (C18O, DCN etc) which do not present strong emission outsid eof the protostellar disk and core, i.e. on <10" scales. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 corresponds to 200 AU at the distance of Serpens and has been chosen to resolve the chemical transition taking place around the CO snowline at ~100 AU.

The requested RMS of 4 mJy per 0.4 km/s is based on existing observations of C18O 2-1 toward similar sources (Jorgensen et al. 2007). They find a peak flux of 0.2-2 Jy/beam with a beam 10x larger than ours. Worst case scenario we thus expect C18O 2-1 fluxes of 20-200 mJy/beam with an averaged expected 100 mJy/beam. To ensure 5sigma detections toward all sources we therefore request an rms of 4 mJy/beam. The bandwidth reference of 0.4km/s is based on expected linewidths of 2km/s and to carry out a kinematic analysis we need at least 5 resolution elements across the line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Serpens H13CN C2H
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of H13CN, C2H, C3H2 and to attempt the detections of CS, c-C3H2, HC15N, CH3OH and SiO toward 5 protostellar disks in Serpens.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.4 km/s, but secondary science on the disk kinematics requires higher spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. Therefore we have opted to observe all target lines at a relative high spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. We have also add what is effectively a 1 GHz continuum band, though we keep it in the spectral line mode at a coarse resolution to enable serendipitous line discoveries, i.e the discovery of hot corinos toward the sample.

These sources are embedded and the largest angular scales for strong linesare thus on the arc minute scale. We are mainly interested in weaker lines (C18O, DCN etc) which do not present strong emission outsid eof the protostellar disk and core, i.e. on <10" scales. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 corresponds to 200 AU at the distance of Serpens and has been chosen to resolve the chemical transition taking place around the CO snowline at ~100 AU.

The requested RMS of 4 mJy per 0.4 km/s is based on existing observations of H13O+ 4-3 toward similar sources (Jorgensen et al. 2007), and observations of H13CN and H13CO+ toward PPDs, which shows that the H13CN flux is typical 0.x that of H13CO+. Jorgensen et al. find a peak flux of 1 or less Jy/beam with a beam 10x larger than ours. We expect the H13CN emission to be compact and thus only reduced by 50% compared to Jorgensen. Taking into account the smaller beam the H13CO+->H13CN conversion and the 4-3 -> 3-2 conversion (another 50%) we expect H13CN 3-2 fluxes of 10-100 mJy/beam with an averaged expected 20 mJy/beam. To detect and resolve the H13Cn emission or derive useful H13CN/C18O upper limit ratios we therefore request an rms of 4 mJy/beam. The bandwidth reference of 0.4km/s is based on expected linewidths of 2km/s and to carry out a kinematic analysis we need at least 5 resolution elements across the line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD163296 C2H
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of C2H, c-C3H2, HCN and other molecular lines toward the PPD around HD 163296

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.5 km/s, but secondary science on the disk kinematics requires higher spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. Therefore we have opted to observe all target lines at a relative high spectral resolution of <0.2km/s wiht the exception of one of the 3 targeted c-C3H2 lines.

The PPD has cleared its enveloped and there is not other nearby large scale structures. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 correspond to ~50AU at the distance of HD 163296, which will allow us to clearly resolve any chemical changes across the 90AU CO snowline. A slightly coarser resolution would have been sufficient, but we chose 0.5" to be consistent across the sample. A smaller beam would start to affect sensitvity.

The requested RMS of 5 mJy per 0.5 km/s is based on a previous 25 mJy/beam detection of c-C3H2 lines toward HD 163296 (the C2H is stronger than the c-C3H2 lines and does therefore not affect the rms request) with a comparable intrinsic intensity. The HD 163296 lines have a width of 8km/s, but the choice of 0.5 km/s bandwidth as a reference is set my the minimum velcoity resolution needed to take advantage of the disk's Keplerian rotation when extracting this and other weak lines.

The high data rate is result of requiring high spectral resolution for all targeted lines, the fact that these lines are spread out between the four different base bands, and requiring at least 1 GHz of total band width to efficiently self calibrate the data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MWC 480 C2H
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of C2H, c-C3H2, HCN and other molecular lines toward the PPDs around MWC 480 and LkCa 15.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.4 km/s, but secondary science on the disk kinematics requires higher spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. Therefore we have opted to observe all target lines at a relative high spectral resolution of <0.2km/s.

These PPDs have cleared their enveloped and there is not other nearby large scale structures. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 correspond to ~75AU at the distance of these Taurus disks, which is just sufficient to resolve any chemical changes across the CO snowline, if it is as epected at 50-100 AU.

The requested RMS of 5 mJy per 0.5 km/s is based on a previous 25 mJy/beam detection of c-C3H2 lines toward HD 163296 (the C2H is stronger than the c-C3H2 lines and does therefore not affect the rms request) with a comparable intrinsic intensity. We expect similar line fluxes toward these disks. The MWC 480 and LkCa 15 lines have widths of 5-6km/s, but the choice of 0.5 km/s bandwidth as a reference is set my the minimum velcoity resolution needed to take advantage of the disk's Keplerian rotation when extracting this and other weak lines.

The high data rate is result of requiring high spectral resolution for all targeted lines, the fact that these lines are spread out between the four different base bands, and requiring at least 1 GHz of total band width to efficiently self calibrate the data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AS209 C2H
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of C2H, c-C3H2, HCN and other molecular lines toward the PPD around AS 209

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.5 km/s, but secondary science on the disk kinematics requires higher spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. Therefore we have opted to observe all target lines at a relative high spectral resolution of <0.2km/s.

The PPD has cleared its enveloped and there is not other nearby large scale structures. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 correspond to ~90AU at the distance of AS209, which will allow us to barely resolve any chemical changes across the a 50-100 AU CO snowline.

The requested RMS of 5 mJy per 0.5 km/s is based on a previous 25 mJy/beam detection of c-C3H2 lines toward HD 163296 (the C2H is stronger than the c-C3H2 lines and does therefore not affect the rms request) with a comparable intrinsic intensity. We expect a similar line flux toward AS 209. The AS 209 lines have a width of 5km/s, but the choice of 0.5 km/s bandwidth as a reference is set my the minimum velcoity resolution needed to take advantage of the disk's Keplerian rotation when extracting this and other weak lines.

The high data rate is result of requiring high spectral resolution for all targeted lines, the fact that these lines are spread out between the four different base bands, and requiring at least 1 GHz of total band width to efficiently self calibrate the data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IM Lup C2H
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of C2H, c-C3H2, HCN and other molecular lines toward the PPD around IM Lup

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.5 km/s, but secondary science on the disk kinematics requires higher spectral resolution of <0.2km/s. Therefore we have opted to observe all target lines at a relative high spectral resolution of <0.2km/s.

The PPD has cleared its enveloped and there is not other nearby large scale structures. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 correspond to ~75AU at the distance of Im Lup, which will allow us to barely resolve any chemical changes across the a 50-100 AU CO snowline.

The requested RMS of 5 mJy per 0.5 km/s is based on a previous 25 mJy/beam detection of c-C3H2 lines toward HD 163296 (the C2H is stronger than the c-C3H2 lines and does therefore not affect the rms request) with a comparable intrinsic intensity. We expect a similar line flux toward IM Lup. The IM Lup lines have a width of 5km/s, but the choice of 0.5 km/s bandwidth as a reference is set my the minimum velcoity resolution needed to take advantage of the disk's Keplerian rotation when extracting this and other weak lines.

The high data rate is result of requiring high spectral resolution for all targeted lines, the fact that these lines are spread out between the four different base bands, and requiring at least 1 GHz of total band width to efficiently self calibrate the data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Upper Sco C2H
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of C2H and HCN and attempt to detect c-C3H2 toward the PPDs around five 5Myr stars in Upper Sco

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.2 km/s for the main line targets HCN and C2H. We have chosen a lower spectral resolution for the expected very weak c-C3H2 lines to obtain a good continuum coverage.

The PPD has cleared its enveloped and there is not other nearby large scale structures. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 correspond to ~75AU at the distance of Upper Sco, which will allow us to barely resolve any chemical changes across the a 30-100 AU CO snowline.

The requested RMS of 4 mJy per 0.4 km/s is based on the scaling of an existing C2H detection toward TW Hya and scaling it for distance and disk mask, and on the smallest line widths of 2km/s in the sample. C2H has been detected toward TW Hya in one of our Cycle 2 programs. If TW Hya was put at the distance of Upper Sco the targeted C2H line should me ~100 mJy/beam. 4/5 of our Upper Sco sources have estimated disk masses of 20% of TW Hya or more and we therefore base our sensitivity estimate on an assumed C2H line strength of 20mJy/beam and a 5sigma detection. To clearly detect the line across the disk we need detections across five channels, i.e. a bandwidth of 0.4 km/s for a 2km/s line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Upper Sco 13CO 2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim is to image the distribution of 13CO, CO and C18O and attempt to detect DCN, H2CO, CH3OH, c-C3H2 and other molecules toward the PPDs around five 5Myr stars in Upper Sco

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our minimum required resolution for the primary science is 0.2 km/s for the main line targets. We have chosen a lower spectral resolution for one band where no strong lines are expected. We keep it in spectral mode to allow for any serendipitous line discovery.

The PPD has cleared its enveloped and there is not other nearby large scale structures. The chosen angular resolution of 0".5 correspond to ~75AU at the distance of Upper Sco, which will allow us to barely resolve any chemical changes across the a 30-100 AU CO snowline.

The requested RMS of 4 mJy per 0.4 km/s is based on the scaling of an existing 13CO observations toward TW Hya and scaling it for distance and disk mask, and on the smallest line widths of 2km/s in the sample. 13CO 2-1 has been detected toward TW Hya in one of our Cycle 2 programs. If TW Hya was put at the distance of Upper Sco the targeted C2H line should me ~250 mJy/beam. 4/5 of our Upper Sco sources have estimated disk masses of 20% of TW Hya or more and we therefore base our sensitivity estimate on an assumed C18O line strength of 50mJy/beam. Since 13CO is our mian probe of disk mass and kinematics we require a 10sigma detection. To clearly detect the line across the disk we need detections across five channels, i.e. a bandwidth of 0.4 km/s for a 2km/s line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The volatile compositions of planets, including water and organic reservoirs, are set by the ice and gas composition of protoplanetary disks. The disk volatile composition, including the elemental division between ice and gas, may change dramatically between the formation of disks in embedded protostars and the time of disk gas dispersal ~5Myrs later. Constraining this chemical evolution at different disk radii is key to predict the composition of planets and planetesimals forming at different disk locations and time scales. We propose to undertake the first systematic exploration of how the disk chemical composition evolves with time, from disk formation in protostars (<0.2Myr) to the oldest (5Myr) surviving protoplanetary disks. The proposed survey sample is drawn from interferometric gas and dust studies of nearby star forming regions of different ages (0.2-5+Myr). The targeted lines have been chosen to primarily probe how the levels of O, C and N sequestration into solids depend on disk evolutionary stage and radius, the key aspect of disk chemistry in the context of planet formation, but we will also cover tracers of H and N fractionation and other time-dependent chemistry.
